stream_context.summary: Kaze collaborates with microcode expert Sauraen in a live technical session to diagnose and debug a major performance issue with the F3DEX3 microcode in 'Return to Yoshi's Island.' While investigating, Kaze also does some 3D modeling for a Mario Kart-themed level.

development_findings.summary: A collaborative debugging session with microcode creator Sauraen revealed that the F3DEX3 performance issue is not primarily due to vertex processing, but a mysterious, unexplained 9-millisecond time loss elsewhere in the microcode's execution.
development_findings.quote: so it's not just that the vertex processing is slower but like that's not all that's happening here something else is taking a ton of time

development_findings.summary: Kaze's game is heavily optimized for RDP performance, using vertex colors for all level lighting and only using dynamic directional lights for actors. This unique setup makes RSP performance the primary bottleneck, unlike in less optimized games like Ocarina of Time.

The team is actively trying to integrate the F3DEX3 microcode to leverage its advanced features, but it's currently causing a significant performance regression, increasing GFX task time from ~21ms to ~27ms.
The debugging process involved live-coding custom performance counters into the N64 microcode's assembly to measure the time spent on vertex and triangle processing independently.
Kaze worked on a Mario Kart 64-themed retro level (Course 12), modeling a starting line and discussing plans for a timed race, a moving train, and other interactive elements.
A technical limitation of Kaze's lighting system (vertex colors for static geometry) is the reason Mario currently appears uncolored when F3DEX3 is active; the GBI commands need to be updated.

context_findings.summary: Kaze articulated a core design philosophy that the game must remain focused on Mario's platforming mechanics, rejecting ideas that deviate into other gameplay styles, even if thematically appropriate.
context_findings.quote: We want the fun to be for Mario's movement and not just random things like that. It kind of feels like, oh, you like Mario 64. Well, fuck you. Here's Mario Kart. I don't want that.

context_findings.summary: Kaze revealed a significant development delay on a 'Bowser magician' boss due to a volunteer contributor failing to deliver promised animations, which has made him wary of open calls for collaboration.
context_findings.quote: Someone offered to do the animations in 2021 and they kept saying I'll do it, I'll do it, I'll do it and then they didn't do it. And that's why you don't do call-ups.

context_findings.summary: The issue of third parties selling romhacks on reproduction cartridges for significant profit was discussed, with both Kaze and Sauraen acknowledging it as a frustrating reality of the scene.
context_findings.quote: I saw in one of the vendors booths they had a bunch of n64 repro carts with romhacks on and there was one that was the missing link... we're seeing that for $50 that obviously none of that money is going to Nintendo but also that money is going to somebody is just taking our stuff and selling it.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expressed a belief that games should be rated on a normal distribution, with most titles falling in the 5-6 out of 10 range.
Kaze uses an old, potentially insecure version of the Project 64 emulator for development convenience, despite being aware of the risks.

zeina.summary: Zeina is slated to work on the animations for the 'Bowser magician' boss, taking over a task that a previous volunteer failed to complete.
Zeina made a brief appearance in the stream chat, showing her engagement with the project's public development.
zeina.quote: Yo, we got a sup from Zeina.

key_stories.title: The F3DEX3 Performance Mystery
key_stories.summary: Kaze and guest expert Sauraen embarked on a deep technical dive to diagnose a performance regression caused by the new F3DEX3 microcode. Through a process of elimination and live assembly coding, they created custom performance counters that uncovered a mysterious 9-millisecond bottleneck, fundamentally changing their understanding of the problem.
key_stories.challenge: The new F3DEX3 microcode, which was supposed to improve performance, was causing a significant slowdown in the game, and the reason was unknown.
key_stories.process: Kaze and microcode creator Sauraen collaborated on a live debugging session. They first established performance baselines with older microcodes. After their initial hypothesis about lighting calculations proved only partially correct, Sauraen live-coded new performance counters into the microcode assembly to isolate the time spent on vertex and triangle processing.
key_stories.outcome: The custom counters revealed a ~9ms 'mystery' time sink not related to vertex or triangle processing. This discovery shifted the focus of the investigation and provided a clear, albeit difficult, path forward for Sauraen to debug the microcode.
key_stories.key_quote: The vertex processing is slower but like that's not all that's happening here something else is taking a ton of time.

key_stories.title: The Unreliable Contributor
key_stories.summary: Kaze revealed that a key boss fight has been on hold since 2021 because a volunteer contributor failed to deliver promised animations. This story illustrates the challenges of managing a distributed, volunteer-based team and the direct impact it can have on a project's scope and timeline.
key_stories.challenge: A planned 'Bowser magician' boss fight has been stalled for years because the necessary animations were never created.
key_stories.process: Kaze accepted an offer from a volunteer contributor in 2021 to create the animations. He then waited for the contributor to deliver, but they repeatedly failed to do so, effectively halting progress on that part of the game.
key_stories.outcome: The feature remains unimplemented, highlighting the risks of relying on unvetted volunteers. The task has now implicitly fallen to Zeina, Kaze's wife and team member, to complete.
key_stories.key_quote: Someone offered to do the animations in 2021 and they kept saying I'll do it, I'll do it, I'll do it and then they didn't do it. And that's why you don't do call-ups.

key_stories.title: Staying True to Mario 64's Core
key_stories.summary: When asked about adding a drivable kart to the Mario Kart 64 level, Kaze articulated a core design pillar for the project. He explained that the game must stay true to Mario 64's platforming, demonstrating his commitment to preserving the spirit of the original game even when adding new content.
key_stories.challenge: While working on a Mario Kart-themed level, the community suggested adding a drivable kart, a feature that could fit the theme but potentially clash with the game's core identity.
key_stories.process: Kaze evaluated the community suggestion against his vision for the project, prioritizing the integrity of the core Mario 64 experience over a thematically-appropriate but mechanically-divergent feature.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze firmly rejected the idea, establishing a clear design principle: features must enhance or support Mario's core platforming mechanics, not replace them with entirely different gameplay loops.
key_stories.key_quote: We want the fun to be for Mario's movement and not just random things like that. It kind of feels like, oh, you like Mario 64. Well, fuck you. Here's Mario Kart. I don't want that.

open_questions.context: The stream focused on diagnosing a major performance issue with the F3DEX3 microcode. The key discovery was a ~9ms block of unexplained processing time.
